title: The long non-coding RNA <italic>Dali</italic> is an epigenetic regulator of neural differentiation
abstract: Many intergenic long noncoding RNA (lncRNA) loci regulate the expression of adjacent protein coding genes. Less clear is whether intergenic lncRNAs commonly regulate transcription by modulating chromatin at genomically distant loci. Here, we report both genomically local and distal RNA-dependent roles of <italic>Dali</italic>, a conserved central nervous system expressed intergenic lncRNA. <italic>Dali</italic> is transcribed downstream of the <italic>Pou3f3</italic> transcription factor gene and its depletion disrupts the differentiation of neuroblastoma cells. Locally, <italic>Dali</italic> transcript regulates transcription of the <italic>Pou3f3</italic> locus. Distally, it preferentially targets active promoters and regulates expression of neural differentiation genes, in part through physical association with the POU3F3 protein. <italic>Dali</italic> interacts with the DNMT1 DNA methyltransferase in mouse and human and regulates DNA methylation status of CpG island-associated promoters in <italic>trans</italic>. These results demonstrate, for the first time, that a single intergenic lncRNA controls the activity and methylation of genomically distal regulatory elements to modulate large-scale transcriptional programmes.
